Setting an agenda for action It is a chilling fact that more than 80 million people in the European Union – a quarter of them children – suffer from poverty. The European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion has been an ambitious step towards tackling this. (cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:14)(cid:9)(cid:6)(cid:30)(cid:12)(cid:6)(cid:12)(cid:3)(cid:14)(cid:30)(cid:23)(cid:7)(cid:6)(cid:4)(cid:24)(cid:24)(cid:8)(cid:13)(cid:5)(cid:31)(cid:6) The idea for the ‘Getting out of Poverty’ brochure was to be anything but institutional. Aimed at the general public, it was to read and look like a regular – if small – newsstand magazine. In a series of special reports, the journalists looked at government and NGO initiatives and their hands-on rapport with people struggling with homelessness, addiction, lack of qualifications or chronic money problems. In Hamburg, a carpenter from Kazakhstan teaches unemployed young men how to fix old steam engines; in Brussels, a young Togolese beautician explains how she opened her beauty salon thanks to a microcredit loan; in southern Spain, a derelict Roma quarter is rebuilt with the help of its residents. Like a breath of fresh air, these real life stories demonstrate that overcoming poverty and social exclusion has to be a collective undertaking. Co-funding for change Around 700 projects and activities in 29 countries were co-financed by the European Commission during the Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion. These were among the year’s key contributions, bringing participative action and change to local levels. European governments either matched the EU contribution, or in some cases, like Germany and Portugal, put in a great deal more. The main approaches of co-financed projects were: • awareness raising through debates, the media, competitions, social networking and solidarity chains; • direct support for poverty and social exclusion programmes; • policy development through conferences, seminars and the introduction of new policy schemes and action plans; • expertise building through research, studies and publications. On Friday, December 17, 2010, EU heads of state and heads of govern- ment gathered for the closing European Council of the year. At the same time up the road, people experiencing poverty and working to combat it were taking part in the summing-up conference of the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion. EN_107850_int.pdf 15 17/08/11 10:05

EUROPEAN YEAR FOR COMBATING POVERTY AND SOCIAL EXCLUSION SPRINGBOARD INTO THE FUTURE 18 More than 80 million Europeans or 17 % of the EU population live below the poverty line, and the economic crisis is not improving matters. A year-end 2010 Eurobarometer survey to bookend the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion paints a grim picture of both the reality and public perceptions of poverty. The European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion mobilised politicians, stake- holders and citizens through thousands of events organised across the EU. Several hundred projects were co-financed by the EU and Member States in 29 countries, involving public administrations, civil society, the media, politicians, experts and citizens. EUROPEAN YEAR FOR COMBATING POVERTY AND SOCIAL EXCLUSION SPRINGBOARD INTO THE FUTURE 20 Four specific strategies are put forward • Active inclusion for all men and women – ie income support, inclusive labour markets and access to quality housing, energy, health care, education and mobility. • Combating child poverty to break the poverty cycle early on. This means, among other things, investing in care and education. • Paying particular attention to such vulnerable groups as migrants, the Roma, ethnic minorities and the homeless. • Economic, employment and social policies must work together and consider their impact on poverty. To this effect, the Structural Funds including the European Social Fund must be targeted effectively and appropriately. EUROPEAN YEAR FOR COMBATING POVERTY AND SOCIAL EXCLUSION SPRINGBOARD INTO THE FUTURE 22 The Platform’s five main action areas • Delivering actions across the policy spectrum, from education to employment to the integration of migrants. • Making greater and more effective use of EU funds to support social inclusion, in particular the European Social Fund. • Promoting evidence-based social innovation involving peer review, mutual learning and transfer of best practices. • Promoting strong partnership between local, regional, national and European stakeholders, and encouraging a social economy. • Enhancing policy cooperation between Member States.
